item.title: About Sponsors
item.description:
Veracel Celulose is a Brazilian company located in southern Bahia, dedicated to the sustainable production of bleached eucalyptus pulp. Formed as a joint venture between the Swedish-Finnish Stora Enso and the Brazilian Suzano Papel e Celulose, Veracel adopts advanced forest management and environmental conservation practices, balancing industrial production with socio-environmental responsibility. The company operates one of the largest pulp mills in Latin America, generating employment and economic development in the region.
A notable initiative by Veracel is the maintenance of conservation areas, such as the Private Reserve of the Natural Heritage (RPPN) Esta o Veracel, located in Porto Seguro, Bahia. Established in 1998, this RPPN protects approximately 6,000 hectares of Atlantic Forest, one of the most biodiverse and threatened biomes in Brazil. The site is recognized by UNESCO as part of the Atlantic Forest Biosphere Reserve and plays a crucial role in the conservation of endangered species, such as the golden-headed lion tamarin. Additionally, the reserve promotes scientific research, environmental education, and sustainable tourism, reinforcing Veracel's commitment to ecosystem preservation and biodiversity enhancement.

item.title: Field Trip
item.description:
The registration fee allows attendants to select one of the field trip options (be aware that some of the field trips have a limited number of participants). Attendants will select their preferences in order of registration.
Trip 1: Landscapes of Coexistence – Forest Productivity Meets Preservation (max 40 attendants).
Emphasis is on Eucalypt plantations, mosaic landscapes integrating production and conservation aspects in a private natural heritage reserve (Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural – RPPN).
Trip 2: Economic, Social and Environmental Conflicts – Cultivating Solutions (max 40 attendants).
This field trip deals with social aspects, the participants will visit communities of small producers and rural settlers, indigenous populations.
Trip 3: Rebuilding Forests – Challenges and Successes (max 40 attendants).
Focusing on restoration of degraded areas with a focus on the conservation of the diversity of native forests of the region. The field trip includes a visit to an RPPN.
Trip 4: Cultural Visit.

Field Activity: DecisionES - Brazil 2025

The planned field activity is a crucial opportunity to connect the theoretical discussions of the symposium with practical applications, allowing participants to observe in loco the dynamics related to ecosystem services, forest restoration, and sustainable management.
This experience complements key themes of the congress, such as the impact of climate change, integrated forest and water resource management, and the restoration of degraded areas. Additionally, the activity reinforces knowledge exchange, contributing to innovative and practical solutions in the global forestry context.
